meaning_mnemonic: The poor <radical>alligator</radical> was taken far inland by a <radical>tsunami</radical>. Now his only source of water is a tiny <kanji>pond</kanji> that barely fits his body, and doesn't even provide much food.

<radical>Ice</radical> is what you're <radical>lack</radical>ing, so the <kanji>next</kanji> thing you need to do is go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!
Just like the radical, the kanji means <kanji>capital</kanji>.

The <radical>branch</radical> radical and the <kanji>branch</kanji> kanji are the same! This kanji also means <kanji>support</kanji>. To remember it, think about a tree with lots of branches. The branches support each other and the trunk of the tree. If you were to climb the tree, the branches would be able to support your weight too!

The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>master</radical>s gets to choose the place they <kanji>dwell</kanji>. So they <kanji>reside</kanji> in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings.
With <radical>top hat</radical> <radical>power</radical>, you're able to <kanji>help</kanji> anyone.
You're in a <radical>cage</radical> and you've been shot by an <radical>arrow</radical>. Obviously things are looking pretty bad. You need some <kanji>medicine</kanji> if you hope to live.

<radical>Wolverine</radical> is going down a <radical>slide</radical> and from your <radical>mouth</radical> you scream, "Hey, <kanji>buddy</kanji>! Watch it with that slide, it's really fast and you might hurt yourself, buddy!" 

You're a really good buddy to Wolverine. He also happens to be the local ruler of these lands. You make it a habit to befriend the local strongmen, just in case… No wonder you're so buddy-buddy with all the rulers around here.

<radical>Writing</radical> and <radical>measurement</radical> stand <kanji>versus</kanji> one another. Writing is all about feeling and expression. Measurement is about cold hard numbers. Yep, in this world writing people are basically the <kanji>opposite</kanji> of measurement people. Which side are you on?

Your nation's <radical>flag</radical> sits on top of a <radical>cape</radical>d <radical>mouth</radical>. This is the symbol for the "<kanji>Bureau</kanji> of Secret Things." It's a special <kanji>department</kanji> of your government made to keep things hidden.

You <radical>loiter</radical> around with a <radical>weapon</radical> because you're currently doing your <kanji>service</kanji> and <kanji>duty</kanji> to your country. You're standing guard outside, waiting just in case something will happen.

In your <radical>fingers</radical> is a <radical>weapon</radical>, so you <kanji>throw</kanji> it. Maybe you're angry and you threw the weapon at a person you don't like. Maybe you're a pacifist and you threw it away so no one else could use it. Either way, when you have a weapon in your fingers you have to throw it.
You have at your disposal a <radical>tsunami</radical> to assassinate this <radical>person</radical>, or a <radical>hook</radical>. Which method will you choose? <kanji>Decide</kanji> now!

You dig a <radical>hole</radical> <radical>nine</radical> times for your <kanji>research</kanji>. You should always do research with nine variables so you can compare them, and so there's an uneven number.

When your <radical>self</radical> goes down a <radical>slide</radical> and hits a <radical>barb</radical>, it's a painful reminder that you have a <kanji>body</kanji>. Sometimes people think their self is just some kind of floating, disembodied consciousness, but getting a barb stuck in <kanji>oneself</kanji> while going down a slide will quickly remind one of one's bodily existence.
The radical and the kanji are exactly the same, so this means <kanji>someone</kanji>.
A <radical>stone</radical> <radical>lantern</radical> is an excellent way to <kanji>sharpen</kanji> anything, even in the dark. Your knives, your forks, your spoons, and even your sword.
The <radical>horse</radical> radical and the <kanji>horse</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
This kanji is just the <radical>tree</radical> radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means "<kanji>forest</kanji>."

<radical>Dirt</radical> makes it <radical>easy</radical> to identify your <kanji>location</kanji>. Even if you add an extra line to mark the ground, it's still easy. Keep that in mind and you can go from <kanji>place</kanji> to place.

There's a <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the top of the <radical>sun</radical> and another <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the bottom. The <radical>moon</radical> is off to the right. That's because it's the <kanji>morning</kanji>, which is when the sun and moon switch over. Those crosses are making sure the sun stays high in the sky for the rest of the day.

You have to <radical>sickle</radical> the <radical>rice paddy</radical> today because it's your <kanji>turn</kanji>. This kanji also means <kanji>number in a series</kanji>, which is a lot like a turn. For example, you're number 3, so your turn will be number 3.
"Does the <radical>bamboo</radical> shirt <radical>suit</radical> me?" you ask... but nobody will <kanji>answer</kanji>.

When a bunch of <radical>thread</radical>s are <radical>meet</radical>ing on paper (after you've dipped them in paint, say) they can create a masterpiece of a <kanji>picture</kanji> (or <kanji>painting</kanji>).

Here's a <radical>net</radical> full of of <radical>shellfish</radical> that you can <kanji>buy</kanji>. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money.

Aim the <radical>scooter</radical>'s <radical>neck</radical> at the <kanji>road</kanji>! Scooters are only meant for driving on <kanji>street</kanji>s and <kanji>path</kanji>s, and if you go the wrong <kanji>way</kanji>, you'll probably break your own neck!

There's a <radical>gate</radical> that the <radical>sun</radical> goes through at a regular <kanji>interval</kanji>. There is an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> in the sense that the sun goes through it at the same time every day. And there is an <kanji>interval of space</kanji> in the sense that it has to go through the space between the gate posts.
A <radical>rain</radical> <radical>cloud</radical> is still a <kanji>cloud</kanji>! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella.

Give <radical>rice</radical> to a <radical>woman</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so she can <kanji>count</kanji> it. The woman will count each individual grain of rice, then tell you the <kanji>amount</kanji> or <kanji>number</kanji> of grains.

The <radical>white</radical> <radical>ice</radical> <radical>tree</radical> is a magical tree that radiates an aura of <kanji>comfort</kanji>, <kanji>ease</kanji>, and <kanji>pleasure</kanji>, with its icy foliage tinkling like beautiful <kanji>music</kanji> whenever it sways in the breeze.
<radical>Say</radical> it with your <radical>tongue</radical>. If you do, you'll be able to <kanji>talk</kanji>. You'll be able to <kanji>speak</kanji>.

You're in the <radical>rain</radical>, in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, holding an <radical>umbrella</radical>. You're here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by <kanji>electricity</kanji> (aka lightning), to prove that it exists.
You're tearing this <radical>door</radical> down with an <radical>axe</radical>. You're absolutely crazy. "I HATE THIS <kanji>PLACE</kanji>!!" you keep yelling as you smash in the door.
Under a <radical>cliff</radical> there's a <radical>stool</radical>. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty <kanji>anti</kanji>-society, hiding away like that.
